citations.narrative:
On December 13, 2025, while performing in a Christmas nativity scene, the licensee's 14-year-old castrated male
dromedary camel kicked a woman in the audience in the head with his back left leg while being led by his handler down
an isle inside a church. The woman, who appeared to be knocked unconscious, was taken to a hospital for evaluation and
treatment. APHIS received videos of the incident from a complainant. During this inspection, the videos were reviewed
with facility representatives who confirmed the aforementioned information. A lack of sufficient distance and/or barriers
between the animal(s) and the viewing public, during periods of public exhibition, can negatively impact the health and
well-being of the public and animal(s).
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals
and the public.
Correct by: January 8, 2026
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On December 13, 2025, while performing in a Christmas nativity scene, the licensee's 14-year-old castrated male 
dromedary camel kicked a woman in the audience in the head with his back left leg while being led by his handler down 
an isle inside a church. The woman, who appeared to be knocked unconscious, was taken to a hospital for evaluation and 
treatment. APHIS received videos of the incident from a complainant. During this inspection, the videos were reviewed 
with facility representatives who confirmed the aforementioned information. A lack of sufficient distance and/or barriers 
between the animal(s) and the viewing public, during periods of public exhibition, can negatively impact the health and 
well-being of the public and animal(s).  
 
During public exhibition, any animal must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with 
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public so as to assure the safety of animals 
and the public.  
 
Correct by: January 8, 2026 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
 n
